journal-meta.journal-title: American Journal of Hospice and Palliative Medicine®

title-group.article-title: Palliative Care and Support for Persons with HIV/AIDS in 7 African Countries
title-group.subtitle: Implementation Experience and Future Priorities

article-meta.aff: 1University of Maryland School of Medicine, Institute of Human Virology, Baltimore, MD, USA

author-notes.corresp: Carla S. Alexander, University of Maryland School of Medicine, Institute of Human Virology, 29 S Greene St Suite 300, Baltimore, MD 21201, USA Email: calexand@medicine.umaryland.edu

abstract.p: To combat morbidity and mortality from the worldwide epidemic of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), the United States Congress implemented a President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) in 30 resource-limited countries to integrate combination antiretroviral therapy (ART) for both prevention and cure. Over 35% of eligible persons have been successfully treated. Initial legislation cited palliative care as an essential aspect of this plan but overall health strengthening became critical to sustainability of programing and funding priorities shifted to assure staffing for care delivery sites; laboratory and pharmaceutical infrastructure; data collection and reporting; and financial management as individual countries are being encouraged to assume control of in-country funding. Given infrastructure requisites, individual care delivery beyond ART management alone has received minimal funding yet care remains necessary for durable viral suppression and overall quality of life for individuals. Technical assistance staff of one implementing partner representing seven African countries met to clarify domains of palliative care compared with the substituted term “care and support” to understand potential gaps in on-going HIV care. They prioritized care needs as: 1) mental health (depression and other mood disorders); 2) communication skills (age-appropriate disclosure of HIV status); 3) support of care-providers (stress management for sustainability of a skilled HIV workforce); 4) Tied Priorities: symptom management in opportunistic infections; end-of-life care; spiritual history-taking; and 5) Tied Priorities: attention to grief-related needs of patients, their families and staff; and management of HIV co-morbidities. This process can inform health policy as funding transitions to new priorities.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In 2009, an estimated 1.8 million people worldwide died due to human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection. At the 2010 International AIDS Society meeting, despite remarkable achievements related to improved survival and treatment as prevention, rising death rates were reported among socially disadvantaged populations from the United States, Brazil, and South Africa. 1 Since 1990, the World Health Organization (WHO) has promoted integration of pain management and palliative care for all countries, 2 highlighting the relief of suffering and promotion of quality of life regardless of the availability of curative interventions in life-threatening illness. 3 Palliative care a critical component of ongoing clinical care attends not only to physical but to psychoemotional, spiritual, and social needs of the individual and his support system throughout the continuum of chronic illness. 4 –6 Initial legislation creating the President’s Emergency Program for AIDS Relief (PEPFAR) in 15 resource-limited countries included palliative care but as implementation efforts to offer antiretroviral therapy (ART) grew to 30 countries, guidance focused upon capacity building and sustainability of services, with only minimal attention to patient-level management issues. 7

To reconcile the global term “palliative care” with internal US funding experience with “hospice,” the US Office of the Global AIDS Coordinator’s (OGAC) Care and Support Working Group created Guidance #1 in 2006 to revise the term “palliative” to “care and support,” resulting in perceived changes in emphasis for local recipients. 2 Despite greater than 20-fold expansion in numbers of people being treated in sub-Saharan Africa over the first 4 years of PEPFAR, 8 up to 35% of those infected with HIV have accessed ART. Persons with HIV, regardless of treatment status, 9,10 suffer with 10 to 26 simultaneous symptoms including fatigue, 11 pain, 12 diarrhea, fevers, cough, and headache plus significant mental health issues, 13 –15 for example, depression, anxiety, grief, 16 sleep difficulties as well as concerns about finances, and stigma. 17
–21 These problems are not solved by ART alone leaving a significant need for providers to address symptom management in the individual.

As PEPFAR funding integrated with local health care policy and delivery, infrastructure needs such as stabilization of electrical power, access to clean water, and safe storage for supplies and equipment were significant. Clinical training, administrative data collection and reporting systems, and laboratory support had to scale-up simultaneously. Shortage of skilled staff resulted in task-shifting methods for individual patient care. 22,23 Activities focused in 6 areas (1) supply chain management for medications and laboratory supplies; (2) laboratory equipment acquisition and maintenance; (3) both operational and clinical data collection and management systems; (4) introduction of quality improvement systems; (5) skilled training for technical and clinical staff; and (6) structuring of new services such as prevention of transmission of the HIV-1 virus from pregnant mothers to children.

Continuous quality improvement efforts have focused upon improving population-focused health delivery and patient education to assure adherence. We have documented that clinical supervision of community support persons can improve adherence and reduce lost to follow-up. 24 Less attention has been paid to individual patient problems. As funding transitions to in-country priority setting, we assembled representatives from recipient countries to clarify strategic priorities for care and support needs of persons with HIV across the continuum of illness. Following review of current models and practices, this multidisciplinary group prioritized future focus areas reflecting patient population needs perceived by technical educators. 4,25

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This article represents discussions among educators of one implementing partner of the US OGAC to introduce HIV care and treatment in targeted resource-constrained settings since 2004. This program, designed to provide rapid scale-up of ART for persons living with HIV in 7 African and 2 Caribbean countries, was grounded in scientific understanding that durable viral suppression for each person would ultimately be the key to both prevention and management of this mutable virus. 26 Guiding principles focused upon patient–family dyad as a unit of care with 3 significant support arms (1) effective point of care laboratory infrastructure for evaluation and monitoring of individual patients; (2) intensive adherence education and support integral to clinical management to achieve viral control; and (3) ongoing use of site-specific data to guide improvement in local care and treatment delivery. 27

Selected ART technical assistance providers from 7 African countries met in Nairobi, Kenya, to clarify care and support priorities for delivery of ART. After reviewing the basic model underpinning care and support used throughout this program, participants shared ongoing in-country activities representing the scope of care and support. Currently, there are almost 400 000 persons on ART, with 85% to 90% adherence rates and 86% to 90% complete viral suppression in randomly selected persons who have been stable on therapy for 9 to 15 months. 28 Domains of care and support in the African context were contrasted with accepted domains of palliative care. Using a nominal process based upon perceived needs at current ART sites, participants identified priorities reflecting the 4-quadrant approach 29 –31 for improving care delivery over the next 5 years.

sec.title: Current Care and Support Activities
sec.p: Each country program identified representatives to focus on care and support activities. In 2008, a small group attended a 10-day experiential introduction to hospice and palliative care programming in the United States that included attending a national industry-sponsored conference. These focal persons returned to their own countries to relay information and develop in-country priorities. Table 1 represents in-country activities following the original orientation. Projects have ranged from simple chart reviews for patient-level needs to providing education related to pain and other symptom management and include more extensive interventions such as clinical screening for malignancy and in-depth interviewing at care delivery sites regarding staff stress and needs of children.

caption.p: Country-Specific Activities to Integrate Care and Support with Ongoing ART

tr.td: Recognition of need for evaluation of patient needs especially pain management and disclosure of HIV status to children

Site-level education with follow-up chart audit regarding implementation of pain and other symptom management; barriers noted:
Poor recognition and management of pain despite education
Lack of consistent documentation
Files/charts of lost-to-follow-up (#147) audited for quality improvement: 57% had CD4 < 100 cells/cc and cough, fever, chest pain, and difficulty breathing
Screening for cervical cancer—integrated project with 19 other collaborators targeting control of cervical cancer in Kenya
Availability of oral morphine for pain management introduced by government: cosponsored staff training with country PC organization

Barriers identified; resource needs clarified Pilot project at 1 clinical site:
Staff interviews: clarify knowledge/attitudes regarding pain
Chart reviews: types of pain in local population: headache most frequent
Poor documentation with regard to pain complaints and follow-up

Barriers identified; resource needs clarified
Staff interviews: overwhelmed
Patient interviews: clarify local terms used to discuss redepression/mood disorders
Staff intervention: to improve morale/overcome burnout perceived to cause providers to with-hold introducing new HIV programming

Barriers identified; resource needs clarified Pilot project at 1 hospital:
Advocacy with staff regarding range of issues to anticipate
Identified need for bereavement training for staff
Implemented “memory board” about patients who died to assist staff in “saying good-bye” to individuals
Identified hospital-based end-of-life team
Recognized need for documentation of spiritual connections of patients upon admission to hospital
Asked spiritual leaders to visit dying patients and their families
Identified need for “scripting” given many distinct tribal/cultural issues in discussing EOL
Recognized need to address care and support grieving needs of orphans and vulnerable children
All in-country trainings to include attention to care of providers
Disclosure to children over 7 years of age—ongoing conducted by government staff; plan for focused educational efforts for children < 7 years

fn.p: Abbreviations: ART, antiretroviral therapy; HIV, human immunodeficiency virus.

sec.title: Model for Integration of Care and Support
sec.p: Although the WHO clinical staging is recognized and used throughout all PEPFAR programming for determining patient clinical status and monitoring of response to ART, these stages have not routinely been associated with specific care and support needs. 35 For teaching purposes, we created a pictorial description of life-time progression of care needs of persons with HIV/AIDS to assist providers in understanding where a patient stands along a continuum of care. 36 This assists clinical staff with understanding psychosocial and spiritual needs at any point of contact with the health care system. 37,38

Stage 1, prevention and engagement in care, of the model begins prior to the first clinic presentation but following HIV diagnosis and extends until the patient is initiated on ART. During this phase, the infected person may be overwhelmed or have serious concerns about the future, about their own ability to cope, and will be aware of stigma within the personal support system and community. Care and support needs differ during stage 2, when ART is initiated and disease begins to stabilize. At this time, education intensifies in preparation for taking medication and developing positive adherence habits. Physical aspects of care tend to dominate this phase of adjustment to HIV disease. Stage 3, health maintenance begins once viral load is controlled. This phase is of prolonged and indeterminate duration but requires attention to concerns such as mental health issues that might impair adherence; family planning and child rearing; or adherence fatigue—all requiring varied and specific knowledge, attitudes, and skills from providers and staff. Stage 4 represents a turning point, a sign to the clinical team that a different approach to ongoing care and support is needed either because of new comorbidity or because of loss of viral control due to resistance to current regimen. Without a radical shift in care delivery, a patient can deteriorate rapidly and die leaving without family and staff unprepared. Effective teamwork can enable this patient to cycle back for a new antiretroviral regimen or other therapy to improve quality of life. Changed adherence messaging will be critical at this time. Appropriate referral and end-of-life care must be offered to those who are no longer able to tolerate ART. When deaths do occur both staff and families are impacted by the loss and need time to grieve effectively to readapt to life without someone they cared for and loved.

sec.title: Domains of palliative care versus care and support
sec.p: Domains of palliative care are recognized internationally 30 and are similar to the term care and support. Following a review of these domains: structure and process; patient–family unit of care; “total,” holistic, or “4-quadrant approach” to patient problems recognizing that all problems have physical, psychosocial, 13 and spiritual aspects 39 ; sustainability of workforce, or care of care providers; and ethical and legal aspects (see Table 2), attendees compared these traditional domains with care and support being implemented within ART care and treatment programs. They observed 3 critical differences (1) inclusion of “prevention” and “safety” emphasized by current funders are an “add-on” to curtail the spread of HIV; (2) “time of focus” or emphasis along the continuum of illness differs with care and support seeming to focus earlier during enhancement of care and health maintenance phases while palliative care recognizes the need for preparation for and experiencing end-of-life plus the aftereffects on family and staff 40 ; and (3) in the African context, the term “beliefs” might be more expressive than “spirituality” as cultural, religious, and spiritual ideas are closely entwined in most countries or tribes and not perceived to be well expressed with spirituality alone.

caption.p: Domains Addressed by Care and Support/Palliative Care Delivery Models

tr.th: Public Health Evaluation Care and Support 22 (Kenya) Phase 1, 2007 to 2009

tr.td: Care of patient/family as unit of care
√ (HAND; mood disorders; substance abuse; violence in home; grief)
√ (Application limited by lack of funding focus)

fn.p: b Nairobi Care and Support Meeting, November 2010.

sec.title: Care and support priorities identified
sec.p: Using small group discussion and a nominal process, participants identified 5 critical areas needed in ongoing ART care and treatment: (1) recognition and management of depression and other mood disorders; (2) age-appropriate disclosure of HIV status for children; (3) stress management for sustainability of a skilled workforce 41 ; (4) tied priorities: attention to actual management of symptoms experienced both from HIV disease and opportunistic infections 20 ; end-of-life care; and spiritual history taking; and (5) tied priorities: grief experienced by both patients and staff that can interfere with effective work completion 42 ; and management of comorbidities of HIV illness (see Figure 1).

caption.p: Priorities for integration of palliative care and support issues with African ART management.

sec.title: Care of providers and reduction of stress to extend current workforce
sec.p: Personal and workplace adaptable stress-relief methods 43 were integrated throughout the workshop including 1 full day devoted to skills building. Attendees identified personal and workplace issues (see Table 3) that interfere with the ability of workers to remain enthusiastic about their work. 44 Workplace factors causing stress to workers 45 include inadequate resources/supplies for sites; heavy workload (eg, too many patients per clinic session); not feeling safe because of multitasking without adequate training and experience; lack of control over change; lack of cohesiveness in workplace priorities—poor consensus on best approach to problem solving; too much time away from home and family to accomplish daily work; lack of appreciation from superiors or from patients; too many deadlines to meet; limited finances/lack of compensation for overtime and inadequate help with problem solving. Teaching staff also noted that caring for children worsens stress because of the overwhelming needs of orphans and vulnerable children. Personal stressors identified include sleep deprivation; family issues; being affected by death of patients; unfulfilled expectations and desires related to personal careers; and inability to provide for family on current income.

caption.p: Staff Perceptions of Stress: Experienced at ART Delivery Sites

tr.td: Workload too heavy; too many patients
Not feeling safe because of multitasking
Unfulfilled expectations and desires related to careers
Unable to provide for family on current income
Poor consensus on best approach to problem solving—priority setting needed
Away from home and family too much
Lack of appreciation from superiors or patients
Lack of effective supervision: no help with problem solving
Caring for children worsens stress because they lack social support
Limited finances/ no per diem for perceived extra duties

sec.p: Having an opportunity to share accomplishments and challenges across settings gave participants insight and a sense of support within the group. Figure 2 documents insights from the group related to patient care and to needs of staff providing care for patients.

caption.p: Lessons learned from multi country review of activities

sec.title: Identification of outcome measures
sec.p: In review of data elements currently being collected, the majority focus on process and physical care delivery; few, if any, focus upon patient-level outcomes such as quality of life. Although only 35% of those eligible for ART are currently on treatment, the focus in many countries remains upon those receiving ART and possibly overlooking nonphysical symptoms. Of the programs represented, few staff members have time or budgets allocated to care for person near the end-of-life care, nor for needs of those awaiting initiation of ART perhaps resulting in loss to follow-up or early death.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This article represents a review of 7 years of implementation of care and support activities identified by providers of technical assistance of one PEPFAR implementing partner. Individual countries reported attempts to document and respond to the needs of patients regarding pain management; efforts to cooperate with in-country screening for malignancies; and to evaluate the impact of teaching interventions. Staff voiced concern about the capacity of well-trained and dedicated providers to keep up the current pace of care and support. Without funding earmarked for such activities, it has proven difficult to focus upon care needs of individual patients.

Participants in this meeting represent the multiple clinical disciplines involved in care and treatment of persons with HIV/AIDS in 7 African countries. They are responsible for providing technical assistance to those who work in local ART clinics and are directly involved in the care of patients. Together they represent 89.5 cumulative years of experience caring for persons with HIV disease in African settings. Although workshop proceedings did not emphasize mental health issues, all participants independently identified depression 46 and other mood disorders as being the symptoms most difficult to deal with in current clinical settings. This unexpected result deserves further investigation as a perceived need in resource-constrained settings and is highlighted in recent literature. 47,48

Psychosocial and spiritual aspects of care may be neglected when physical aspects are emphasized in disease management. 9 Use of a model for identifying care and support needs across the continuum of illness may be useful to providers but those trained to employ the WHO staging system for disease severity may have difficulty integrating secondary aspects of care and treatment. This raises the point that care delivery might better be presented with basic HIV management strategy rather than as an add-on to medical management.

Current data collection must be reviewed for gaps related to patient-level outcomes beyond the physical. 10 To better target patient needs, care and support outcomes must be monitored routinely along with other process indicators. Until all HIV-infected persons have access to ART, funding sources may need to designate funds to keep persons engaged in care while awaiting treatment 49 and attend to the needs of the majority without access to therapy or who may need end-of-life care. 1,50 This discussion highlights possible future directions for operational research 51 and care delivery for improving care and support of persons with HIV disease in resource-limited settings. 7

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: We thank the patients and staff of clinics and hospitals receiving care and treatment and the Ministries of Health with whom we work.

fn.p: The authors declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.

The authors disclosed receipt of the following financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article: PEPFAR-Rapid Expansion for HIV+ Persons in Africa funded by Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA) to Catholic Relief Services to University of Maryland School of Medicine - Institute of Human Virology for Training and Technical Assistance in Africa and Caribbean Regions.
